title: Labour-Practice Responses to Ethical-Trading Codes of Conduct at Sites of Production: A Case Study of the Sri Lankan Apparel Sector
abstractText: Corporate codes of conduct are used to promote social justice and ensure worker welfare via the maintenance of minimum labour standards at sites of production.  Yet these "global" regulatory initiatives are primarily driven from the Global North, whether because of consumer campaigns or retailers yielding to consumer and NGO pressure.  Consequently, there remains a lacuna relating to the integration of the voice of labour and concerns of the Global South into these regulatory frameworks.  Dr. Ruwanpuraâ€™s project attempt to fill this gap by assessing how labour practices in the apparel sector in Sri Lanka have been impacted by the ethical trading codes of conduct employed and the social auditing methods adopted.  It will provide an in-depth study of evolving labour conditions and practices focused on the experiences and perceptions of workers from a sample of apparel producers and factories accessing the workers via resident boarding houses.  A focus on the lived realities of labourers in the Sri Lankan clothing sector is likely to fill a significant research gap by advancing knowledge of how global production processes are shaped by ethical trade initiatives and the extent to which codes of conduct are perceived by workers as bettering work conditions.
